29.92.text:
Welcome to Fieldsports Britain. Coming up
Andy Crow is so impressed with Roy's homemade

36.83.text:
night vision last week that he is trying out
his own one this evening.

40.29.text: That has got a dead rat.

42.77.text:
We are going pheasant shooting in the Blackdowns
and we are meeting the founder of a new website

50.17.text:
First they call the goshawk the cook's bird
for its ability to fill your freezer. Well

56.51.text:
nobody told Roy Lupton's Goshawks. He is out
after pheasants with the plangeres of the

65.46.text:
This is a young goshawk. A few 100 years ago
she was the equivalent of ocado the perfect

70.42.text:
predator to put food on the table. Hares,
rabbits, pheasants. She was a vital part of

76.01.text:
any kitchen's utensil drawer. So today we
are off to God's larder to see what she can

82.05.text:
get her talons into and what we can get our
teeth into.

86.10.text:
Today we are going to be going out and seeing
if we can get a few bits and bobs for the

92.20.text:
pot. We are hoping for may be a rabbit and
hopefully a pheasant or two. We have got Jordan

96.10.text:
out with us today as well flying his red tail.
Jordan is my apprentice. He came, or he started

101.51.text:
coming down and we got him doing all the mucky
jobs, clearing out and doing all the normal

106.51.text:
things we get apprentices to do for a year.
At the beginning of this season he started

111.20.text:
off with his red tail. For a ginger he is
definitely not doing to bad. He has worked

115.99.text:
out quite well. He is turning into quite a
good little falconer. I say little he is actually

126.18.text:
huge. Have you seen the size of the boy's
hands.

133.67.text:
I don't know. Girls beware. Anyway we have
got Jordan is out with us with his red tail.

143.40.text:
We are going to give Jordan first dibs to
try and catch a rabbit, but a lot of people

148.91.text:
don't bother flying red tails off the fist
at pheasants and feathered game, but she has

154.90.text:
done very, very well so far on feathered game.
So if we do get a slip on a pheasant hopefully

159.38.text:
we will get one for Jordan. We will see if
his red tail can perform on those as well.

164.61.text:
Roy's issues with red heads and men with big
hands coming to the fore there. Where were

170.26.text:
we, oh yes falconry. Another essential part
of the shopping trip is ferrets. Roy has brought

175.68.text:
along a few bright albino flavours. With young
birds it is best to have these amazing feisty

181.64.text:
little creatures looking as unlike a rabbit
as possible. The first set of burrows is tricky

186.83.text:
to manage as there has been some hedge trimming
so we move on. Now many people start their

191.86.text:
falconry career with a harris hawk, but Roy
commends a red tail as a starter bird for

197.15.text:
Jordan. It will be a bit more work but there
are some long term benefits.

200.86.text:
I think it is a shame that apprentices don't
start off their falconry careers with birds

207.70.text:
like red tails, because they are little bit
more difficult and take a little more understanding

212.80.text:
that the harris hawk. So for an entry level
bird, your first bird you can learn and gauge

218.12.text:
a lot more from them. That is with all of
them. A lot of people will buy a new bird

223.83.text:
and then move straight on after a year or
two to something else. Whereas they are all

228.32.text:
fantastic birds and they will all last you
a good 15 to 20 years of a hunting career.

234.58.text:
We have more success at the next spot. But
the fences are a real problem in this part

239.53.text:
of the world and the rabbits are neatly evading
the wire which could easily kill or end the

245.87.text:
Unfortunately when you are flying here in
this area of the country we are hounded by

251.34.text:
fences and fences are something you have to
be very mindful of and very aware of because

256.03.text:
your hawk can get badly damaged on them. I
was hoping the rabbits were just going to

260.64.text:
come out or maybe go across to that hedgerow
over there, but they are just weaving their

265.60.text:
way down. So we have just got to be a little
bit careful with this earth. We will lift

270.27.text: the ferrets up and move on.

270.37.text:
Moving across the fields, Roy's other shopping
assistant Atos looks like he's on point..

275.39.text:
It could be our first pheasant flight so we
all get into position.

288.71.text:
The hen bird flies along the ditch and manages
to find cover... and the goshawk runs out

293.21.text:
of room. Roy feels it's a case of a fast pheasant
and a young gos with a confidence issue...

298.94.text:
but on we go and Jordan's red tail gets more
of a dive than a flight - incredibly the bird

303.99.text:
is strong enough to keep hold of a bouncing
bunny with a very sharp toe.

308.68.text:
That is the advantage with a red tail, they
are so robust and so strong, she had hold

309.94.text:
of that with one leg, but she stopped it from
running down the hole. But hopefully we will

317.68.text:
Well at least we won't starve - there's a
rabbit in the bag and moments later there's

321.34.text:
another opportunity for the gos - she's a
gnat's earlobe away from making contact...before

326.85.text:
a second dive - nice effort but still not
off the board yet!

331.77.text:
Atos once more smells a nervous pheasant and
we're away again - but this super fast gos

336.64.text:
needs a bit more practise on these flying
feasts.

340.63.text:
Our last chance falls to Jordan - with so
many holes from where a fleet-of-foot rabbit

345.10.text:
will dart, running for its life, it's pretty
hard, especially when there's a small tree

349.29.text:
in the way - the head start means the red
tail has too much ground to make - but it's

361.63.text:
Not quite the day we were looking for. Unfortunately
only a couple of pheasants kicked up there.

366.33.text:
So we have got a few invites towards the end
of the season on a few shoots so we will get

371.14.text:
on there and see if we can do a little bit
better than that. It was the first time this

374.36.text:
hawk has been flown on pheasants and the first
time she has seen pheasants. She flew one

380.53.text:
reasonably well, but obviously the first time
you show them, they are not overly confident

385.62.text:
and then taking a young hawk out at this time
of the season the pheasants are all very fit

390.07.text:
rather than starting at the beginning. I am
just getting my excuses in quick here. Obviously

395.14.text:
we had a very short one with Jordan's bird
and it was just the luck of the bolts, because

399.70.text:
we obviously had a couple of fantastic bolts
that went right across the open field for

403.10.text:
us, but it was just a combination of being
in the wrong spot and not seeing them. I think

408.90.text:
the moral of the story for that one is must
try harder.

411.26.text:
It is a really exciting way to spend an afternoon
even if you have just got one rabbit to show

416.37.text:
for it. Roy is now determined to put on a
show before the end of the season.

423.10.text:
Well that is enough chasing after the birds.
If you want to watch more of our falconry

426.33.text:
films you can click on the films appearing
in the sky behind me and go straight through

433.44.text:
Now something for the birds to chase after
themselves. It is David on the Fieldsports

449.86.text:
The booming population of British roe deer
appears to be having an impact on woodlands.

455.07.text:
That's one conclusion of a new study by Durham
University and the Food and Environment Research

460.33.text:
Agency. Researchers found that sites with
the highest abundance of the native animals

465.29.text:
had the lowest shrub layer vegetation cover
and a lower number of birds, though they haven't

470.61.text:
ruled out that roe deer might just like that
kind of ground.

475.55.text:
News coverage and comment continues about
the RSPCA's vendetta against the Heythrop

480.52.text:
hunt and in particular huntsman Julian Barnfield.
Julian has now retired after a distinguished

486.55.text:
career hunting the Bramham Moor, the Worcestershire
and the Cotswold before the Heythrop. There

490.77.text:
will be a special meet of the Heythrop hounds
in February for all Julian's friends from

494.95.text:
far and wide at which a cap will be taken
for his Testimonial. Contact Heythrop Joint

503.18.text:
Fidel Castro, OJ Simpson, Osama Bin Laden,
America has a new hate figure and he's British:

511.38.text:
Piers Morgan. The CNN star interviewer has
taken a strong anti-gun line since the Sandy

516.46.text:
Point school shootings. The American public
is slating him for his ‘rudeness' to pro-gun

520.43.text:
guests. More than 100,000 Americans have signed
a petition calling for Piers Morgan to be

527.21.text:
Good news for sea fishers who have reported
greater numbers and larger sizes of bluefin

531.86.text:
tuna in British waters. A 500lb bluefin tuna
has sold in Japan for a record sum of £1.2

539.96.text:
million. It went to a sushi restaurant owner
at a Tokyo fish market's first auction of

544.45.text:
the year, setting a new price record - nearly
three times the one set last year. Market

549.83.text:
officials say that this fish was caught off
the coast of north-eastern Japan.

555.39.text:
And finally, a deer surprised shoppers at
the Christmas sales in a town in Essex. A

560.89.text:
woman was injured after the animal went charging
down Chelmsford High Street in Essex. It was

569.02.text:
You are now up to date with Fieldsports Britain
News. Stalking the stories. Fishing for facts.

580.86.text:
Thank you David. Now to the Blackdown hills
of Somerset, which for those of us who live

586.44.text:
in Somerset know are called the Blackdown
hills because it always rains.

591.93.text:
The weather is not looking promising as guns
assemble at Trickey's Farm in Somerset. The

597.70.text:
drizzle only stops to make way for downpours.
Everybody is delighted to be under cover of

604.87.text:
12 people are shooting and sharing the beating
today, from young to old and none of them

613.30.text:
The boss, gamekeeper, farmer - call him what
you like -gives the safety briefing, paying

618.74.text:
special attention to the local horse-owners
on a neighbouring piece of land who don't

623.13.text:
like shot raining down on their four-legged
friends.

627.24.text:
The shooters have their own animal buddies
- the dogs, an unusual collection, not all

632.35.text:
of them Kennel Club-registered - but they
are united in looking forward to not just

637.89.text: shot, but birds raining down on them.

641.55.text:
On the first drive, we join farmer's son Chris.
So what is his father trying to achieve with

652.78.text:
I am a stockman through and through. I milk
the cows seven days a week and I rear the

657.43.text:
birds. I don't shoot myself, but I enjoy the
day and I enjoy rearing the birds and I enjoy

663.64.text:
So as a game keeper have you got a view about
the weather.

667.70.text:
Yes, it is atrocious this year. Absolutely.
The only good thing is on a day like today

670.61.text:
the birds are around the pens. Whereas on
a bright sunny day they tend to be scattered

676.13.text:
Just tell me a bit about the Blackdown hills.
Which is where we are. What sort of shooting

680.15.text:
It is primarily brilliant shooting country.
There are hills, valleys, woods, common land.

687.95.text:
It is just a brilliant area to shoot in. The
only snag being, because it is a brilliant

692.29.text:
area for shooting, it is a brilliant area
for vermin and that is the only snag and we

697.01.text:
do have to work hard in keeping the foxes
down. That is primarily the biggest killer

701.79.text:
of the pheasants. Primarily when they are
poults just out of the pens.

705.76.text:
This shoot is providing excellent sport today
and both the guns and the dogs are getting

711.62.text:
One of the guns today is Sam Clatworthy. Sam
is making waves in the world of shooting with

717.73.text:
Well basically it is a site that allows anybody
to register whether you are a commercial enterprise

724.50.text:
looking to sell days or whether you are on
a syndicate such as myself and you want to

728.84.text:
swap with somebody else to shoot or fish anywhere
else. The beauty of it is, you don't necessarily

736.84.text:
have to pay, you don't have to pay to be part
of a syndicate, you can have access to pheasant

742.36.text:
shooting for free and if you wanted to trade
that day to go and shoot somewhere else it

745.96.text:
doesn't actually cost you any money. You could
trade to do something that would cost you

750.99.text:
money that is the biggest point of it. It
is just to get people to move about a bit

754.96.text:
And does it have to be pheasants or fish or
could it be any kind?

758.87.text:
It can be literally be anything. If you wanted
to put a day out ferreting. If you have access

764.37.text:
to go out and do some really good ferreting,
why not put it on there and see what trade

770.03.text:
offers you get sent really. You get pigeon
shooting, deep sea fishing, trout fishing.

776.16.text:
And if you have pigeon shooting for other
people does that mean you look after them

782.34.text:
Basically, yes. It stipulates that you have
to host on the day. So if we were to exchange

786.01.text:
a day you would be there with me for the day
and then I would go with you for the day.

789.84.text:
That is kind of what it is like. It is just
basically trading days out really, especially

794.40.text:
if you can do it for a nominal fee that is
what it is about really.

797.69.text: It sounds like an on line dating agency.

800.27.text:
It could well be that, but plenty of realtree
I expect that it what it will be.

805.60.text:
So Sam may prefer his pigeon shooting or his
deerstalking to a day on the pheasants, but

810.71.text:
the guns are united in liking this kind of
a pheasant day, where everyone is friends

818.00.text:
Now Somerset is prime shooting for prime pheasant
shooting country, you could turn this into

826.87.text:
You could possibly, but that doesn't interest
me that side of it. We are a dairy farm. This

832.54.text:
is my hobby and that is as far as it will
go. I enjoy the crowd that we shoot with.

837.81.text:
It is a regular crowd of people. I wouldn't
be happy with a load of strangers coming in

842.73.text:
every day and I would feel pressure having
to provide birds. Whereas because it is a

849.26.text:
small syndicate, if we don't shoot them today
they are there next time.

853.71.text:
Trickey's Farm Shoot is run, as shoots should
be, for fun. For more information about Sam's

864.57.text:
Next Andy Crow has got his hands on some night
vision. Look out wild life.

869.39.text:
Last week we brought you Roy getting to grips
with night vision in his bathroom - well Mr

877.60.text:
Crow also has a big problem with rats at the
moment... AND a problem with the quality of

884.40.text: Roy's was a waste of time.

885.85.text:
A faulty door on a new straw barn has left
Andy's bales exposed to rat attack and it

892.36.text:
There have been other bales parked here. This
is where they started chewing it. They chew

894.72.text:
through the net wrap to get to the corn, because
there is no feed. The only feed is in these.

900.97.text:
This one here - you can see this look, they
have chewed all this into it. This is rape

907.54.text:
straw, we have got rat poison in here, but
why do they want to go for the rat poison

911.62.text:
when they can chew into these bales and find
the odd bit of grain in there.

915.80.text:
So what's to be done - well Andy's brought
in an old friend to tackle the problem and

921.13.text:
to have some seriously good sport. Dave, like
so many of you out there likes to use a bit

926.48.text:
of initiative, or in other words ebay, to
open up new air rifling opportunities and

932.72.text: he's agreed to talk us through it.

934.89.text:
Ok well I have bought this old camcorder off
ebay, but you must make sure you use the night

944.82.text:
shot mode ok. There is a lot of camcorders
out there but you must make sure it has got

949.36.text:
this night mode shot on it. I basically got....there
is a thread by the front of the lense and

955.32.text:
I bought this adaptor which is like a filter
wheel or something like that and araldited

961.53.text:
it on to this old lense cap. So that then
screws, if I line it up, yes it does screw

970.04.text:
onto there like that, screws on there. I just
put that around there, pop that on that ok.

977.41.text:
This is a hawk scope. Now slightly crude this
piece of plastic and this very important piece

986.49.text:
of cardboard goes in there to sort the height
out. I will make the proper thing one day.

992.96.text:
Courtesy of the Post Office, elastic bands,
put around that battery and that camcorder

998.24.text:
as crude as it is, is actually is now nicely
on there and that is not going to fall off.

1004.78.text:
Ok now it does have its own infra red illuminator
on this side here which you would use if you

1011.53.text: were filming people if you were

1013.30.text:
standing two or three metres away from them.
That is pretty much as good as they get. Now

1017.54.text:
obviously if we do this in there it just gets
lost and you can see it is tucked behind so

1022.05.text:
much stuff here it would never get out there.
So then you obviously introduce this which

1026.96.text:
is an infra red laser it works off this small
battery pack here which are four AA's, it

1032.77.text:
has this on off switch which I put behind
this rubber band here and you just squeeze.

1036.64.text:
I would do it this side actually if I was
left handed, just squeeze that like that on

1043.67.text:
and off and as I say I haven't done a lot
of this yet, but it seems to be as you know

1047.85.text: it seems to be getting the results we need.

1051.82.text:
I don't want to be getting involved with anything
like that to be honest. So yes, that is pretty

1058.44.text:
much the set up. A lot of this you can see
is home made but in a way that is the glory

1064.73.text:
of how cheap this sort of stuff is now to
buy.

1066.97.text: Yes, it is not three or four grand.

1071.09.text:
So how much do you reckon this lot has cost
you?

1072.37.text: Well obviously we know the rifle is not cheap....

1074.82.text: No just the night sight bit.

1078.19.text:
Got this for £70, the rubber bands I got
off the post man at Christmas.

1084.70.text:
Packing plastic from my house. Filter wheel
I think literally £2 off ebay. Old scope

1091.93.text:
lense, old scope cap, some araldite so we
are still not up to a lot of money. This I

1098.90.text:
think, I would have to look, they are about
£100 I think. It is an infra red laser. There

1104.93.text:
are lots on Youtube. A lot of airgun people
doing this and you can see them. They have

1109.48.text:
got similar set ups, but people just change
it slightly to what they want really.

1114.03.text:
So we're looking at about 200 pounds for Dave's
set-up but after last week's programme we

1118.56.text:
had a few emails, about night vision bargains
including one from Stephen Stubbs from the

1124.72.text:
PigeonWatch forum who made his set-up for
52 pounds... If you are watching this on YouTube,

1130.48.text:
click on the link on the screen to look at
his videos of how he did that. If any one

1135.20.text:
else has some cost saving tips, night vision
or otherwise we'd love to hear about them.

1141.07.text:
Back to rats and Andy's not just here to look
pretty and shout encouragement in the dark.

1146.19.text:
He's the Goose to Dave's Maverick, guiding
towards the intended target. Talk to me, Goose.

1152.28.text:
I spot them with this. It is like a binocular
just look through. I look right round the

1157.97.text:
shed, find the rat and then David, he has
got his spotter on the top, but when he puts

1164.37.text:
that on it it is bright and I can see where
it is in the shed and I just talk him in right,

1168.54.text:
right, right, left, left, left and he goes
onto it. And as soon as he is on it because

1173.40.text:
that is so tight, as soon as he is on it he
can see it on the screen. Gets the cross hair

1179.25.text:
Now, although what follows is a fine example
of precision pest control - at times it might

1184.92.text:
sound as if pilot and navigator are strapped
in to different aircraft.. let's start with

1190.51.text:
a bit of rat on rat action and then Dave and
Andy can take it away....

1194.39.text: There we go....I told you there were two there.

1194.61.text: What the hell....that has got a dead rat.

1194.80.text: He has and all, he has.

1194.99.text:
You have got to kill that. You are recording
it as well.

1201.58.text: Where has he gone....there he is .......

1202.09.text:
Right, right, right, uppy, uppy.......uppy,
uppy a bit.....righty, righty...

1205.46.text: Where is it......it is round the back

1211.95.text:
Down, down, down, get on down, left in there,
right, right, right

1262.28.text:
I can't get in there........ I have got no
pellets left.

1272.21.text:
There he is. There's two more down there.
They will come back out, there you go.

1275.12.text: No, down, down, down near the camera

1277.33.text: I can't remember where it is......

1287.72.text: .....up, up, up there can you see it?

1313.36.text:
Ready.....right fast, fast, stop, up, right
there.....

1325.26.text:
Right, right, right, stop there about.....there
he is.

1350.04.text:
That last rat wasn't a beaver! But then again
Andy doesn't take a size 5 Jack Pyke boot

1355.75.text:
My feet are a size seven and half. These rats
are........I would say he is about a good

1364.79.text:
18" long head to toe. We will take him home
and eat him.

1371.71.text:
It's been a successful evening's ratting and
although we thought night vision would spoil

1375.84.text:
the social side of shooting - this method
certainly keeps everyone involved and entertained.

1381.87.text:
And remember if you have got a simple but
effective way of saving your fellow shooters

1386.05.text:
a few pounds with night vision or anything
else, drop me a line and we'll spread the

1395.95.text:
From the world of hunting, shooting, fishing
in England to the wider world on Youtube.

1406.61.text:
This is Hunting YouTube, which aims to show
the best hunting, shooting and fishing videos

1411.78.text:
Lots of viewers want us to make wildfowling
films and we haven't done it for ages so,

1415.90.text:
in the meantime, if you haven't seen it, take
a look at An Introduction to Wildfowling from

1419.45.text:
BASCFilms. It is a great piece about what
is involved and what's to love about the sport.

1424.61.text:
Staying with shotguns, TweedsandPheasants
sends us his latest of a Boxing Day driven

1428.66.text:
pheasant shoot in Gloucestershire. He has
a new gun, a Miroku MK38 Grade 5 32inch, and

1435.70.text:
Once in a while, it's a real joy to find a
channel of well-edited films from a foreign

1439.83.text:
country where the hunting itself tells the
story. This is the case with Avkulubu2 from

1446.64.text: Turkey. And here is its latest film.

1449.03.text:
For fishing, take a look at this item in English
about salmon deciding whether or not they

1452.65.text:
are in the mood to hook themselves. Salmon
fishing in Iceland with underwater camera

1458.36.text:
Here's a good idea for a film. It is sunrise
on the sea in Massachussetts and sunrise on

1462.62.text:
the 2013 fishing season. For five minutes
you get a bloke beachcasting, but it's rather

1467.49.text:
beautiful. Worth projecting this film on a
wall.

1470.42.text:
From France, ChasseWCamera shows a wild boar
driven day where he shoots two. Just like

1475.67.text:
in Turkey, it doesn't need any funny foreign
languages. Any hunter will understand this

1480.68.text:
Now, anyone who thinks it's just well-practiced
continentals who cans hoot boar, think again.

1485.20.text:
John Morgan sends us this film of three wild
boar he shot in Croatia in December with sporting

1490.14.text:
agent Tomo Svetic of Artemis. Rifle is a borrowed
Steyr Mannlicher Scout in .308. If I were

1496.26.text:
John, I would be quite pleased with this,
so if you know John and for any reason he

1499.96.text: hasn't mentioned this film, here it is.

1502.77.text:
Finally, anyone who wondered if a hare can
swim and who enjoys their dog work will like

1506.65.text:
this from Sweden. I won't attempt to pronounce
the title. All right I will then. Harjakt

1511.91.text:
smålandsstövaren Diva 1.5 år och simmande

1517.15.text:
You can click on any of these films to watch

1520.53.text:
like us to pop in to the weekly top eight,

1528.25.text:
Well we have gots lots of stuff for you so
don't end your TV entertainment just because

1533.09.text:
our show is over. You can go to Schools Challenge
TV which has just launched. It is the programme

1540.08.text:
if you want to get into shooting. The Schools
Challenge is a year long initiative of clay

1546.27.text:
shooting and other shooting events for kids
under the age of 21 and for grown ups. If

1553.19.text:
you like to sit down or lie down for a good
long read well we have got the word's version

1559.49.text:
of Fieldsports Britain that is out every week.
Our newsletter is on scribbed. Don't be put

1564.70.text:
off by the name, click on the link on the
screen and you can go and see it. It is an

1569.83.text:
in depth look at everything we do with Fieldsports
Britain and a little bit of behind the scenes

1577.01.text:
If you are watching this on Youtube don't
hesitate to hit the subscribe button that

1580.88.text:
is as usual somewhere around the outside of
the screen. Or you can go to our web page

1586.20.text:
www.fieldsportschannel.tv where you can click
to like us on Facebook, or follow us on Twitter,

1590.83.text:
or pop your email address into the constant
contact form that is somewhere down on the

1594.64.text:
bottom right of the screen. All those three
things will help you to our free weekly newsletter

1599.60.text:
as well as news of our programme. This has
been Fieldsports Britain. Next week from the

1604.72.text:
greatest gun show in the world, we are going
to Las Vegas.
